intro: Scleranthus augustae, commonly known as the August sow-thistle, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Chenopodiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and hairy stems. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in late summer, typically from July to September. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in arid conditions. Scleranthus augustae is often found in disturbed soils, such as roadsides and fields, and is adapted to thrive in dry environments.
